title: Introduction to R Markdown
text:
Headings are proceed by #. The number of # at the beginning of a line indicates the level of heading (main section, sub section, sub-sub section, etc.)
Here is an illustration.

title: Introduction to R Markdown
text:
H2 level
This is header level 2

H3 level
This is header level 3 and so on.

title: Introduction to R Markdown
text:
More examples
Example 1: Fraction ()
\[\frac{a}{b}=\frac{c}{b}\]
Example 2: Bold math symbols
\[\mathbf{(X'X)^{-1}X'Y}\]
Example 3: Summation, Superscript (^) and Subscript (_)
\[\sum_{i=1}^{n}{x_i^2}\]
Example 4: Equation with multiple lines
Example 4.1:
[ \[\begin{eqnarray}
P(|X-\mu| > k) & = & P(|X-\mu|^2 > k^2)\\
& \leq & \frac{\mathbb{E}\left[|X-\mu|^2\right]}{k^2}\\
& \leq & \frac{\mathrm{Var}[X]}{k^2}
\end{eqnarray}\] ]
Example 4.2:
[ \[\begin{eqnarray}
X & \sim & \mathrm{N}(0,1)\\
Y & \sim & \chi^2_{n-p}\\
R & \equiv & X/Y \sim t_{n-p}
\end{eqnarray}\] ]

title: Working with R codes
text:
Working with R codes


1

set.seed(20205)
x <- rnorm(10)
summary(x)

library(tidyverse)
qplot(data=iris, x=Sepal.Length, y=Sepal.Width, geom="point")










6

qplot(data=iris, x=Sepal.Length, y=Sepal.Width, geom="point")




Figure 1: Scatterplot of Sepal Width vs Sepal Length






7

qplot(data=iris, x=Sepal.Length, y=Sepal.Width, geom="point")










8

qplot(data=iris, x=Sepal.Length, y=Sepal.Width, geom="point")










6. Mathematical Formulae
The general formula for the probability density function of the normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma\) is given by
\[
f_X(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{(2\pi)}} e^{-(x-\mu)^2/2\sigma^2}.
\]


7. Tables

library(knitr)
kable(iris[1:5,], caption="A knitr kable 1")

Colons can be used to align columns.



Column 1

Column 3




Tim
Positive
USA

Negative
UK

Negative
AUS



There must be at least 3 dashes separating each header cell. The outer pipes (|) are optional, and you don‚Äôt need to make the raw Markdown line up prettily. You can also use inline Markdown.


Include an Image


knitr::include_graphics("img.png")




Descriptive Statistics vs Sampling Statistics





library(here)

here() starts at C:/Users/DELL/Documents/rprogramming

knitr::include_graphics(here("rmarkdown", "fig", "sy1.jpg"))









knitr::include_graphics("fig/sy1.jpg")
